###  Wildfire Management Data App

While interning for The Nature Conservancy, I created a web app using Python and Streamlit to make critical wildfire management data more accessible to landowners in Bristol Bay, Alaska. Users select the data layers and data format they are interested in and draw a boundary on the map. The output is either a tif file or pdf map of the data clipped to their boundary. 

<br>
Key skills: Python, ArcGIS Pro, automated geoprocessing, data cleaning & visualization, creative problem solving
Python modules utilized: streamlit, folium, numpy, rasterio, matplotlib, and geopandas

[Click here to view the app](https://bbwildfire.streamlit.app) - may take a moment to render

[Click here to view the github repository](https://github.com/azirkes1/bb_wildfire)

<br>

<img src="assets/photo_storage/wildfire_app.png" alt="wildfire management data app interface" width="900" style="border-radius: 8px;"/>

*Wildfire Management App interface*
:::
:::

### Burn Severity and Vegetation Recovery Tool

Alongside the Wildfire Management Data App, I also developed Google Earth Engine code to help land managers in Bristol Bay, Alaska assess burn severity and vegetation recovery after wildfires. This code uses Landsat and Sentinel 2 imagery to calculate the differenced Normalized Burn Ratio (dNBR) and the differenced Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (dNDVI). In addition, I recorded a tutorial as this tool is intended for users who have little to no experience with Google Earth Engine. 

<br>

Key skills: JavaScript, Google Earth Engine, satellite image processing, remote sensing indices, fire ecology 

[Click here to view the code](https://code.earthengine.google.com/57b233e295913b25d46a30bd0c9a003a) - requires a Google Earth Engine account

[Click here to view the tutorial](https://youtu.be/ZxnXXN5S_Vk)

<br>
<img src="assets/photo_storage/Koktuli_dNBR.jpg" alt="dNBR of Koktuli River fire" width="900" style="border-radius: 8px;"/>

*dNBR output for the Koktuli River fire, which burned in Bristol Bay, Alaska in 2022.*
:::
:::

### Devon Ice Cap Retreat, Velocity, and Elevation Analysis

As a final project during my master's coursework, I measured the retreat of Devon Ice Cap with SWIR1 band differencing. I used Landsat imagery and Google Earth Engine for this analysis. I also analyzed global glacier datasets to investigate changes in velocity and elevation on this ice cap and created visualizations in ArcGIS Pro. 

<br>
Key skills: Google Earth Engine, ArcGIS Pro, Remote sensing indices, and data wrangling, management, & visualization

[Click here to read the final report](assets/doc_storage/Devon_icecap.docx) 

<br>

<img src="assets/photo_storage/Devon_retreat.jpg" alt="map of retreat on Devon ice cap" width="900" style="border-radius: 8px;"/>

*Retreat of Devon Ice Cap 1987 – 2024. Total retreat measured is 617 km2.*
:::
:::

<br>

I researched the use of remote sensing tools for detecting permafrost thaw and building damage, and synthesized findings in an in-depth literature review as a final project during my master's coursework. 

<br>

Key skills: technical writing, interdisciplinary research, organization

### LGBTQ+ Youth Spatial Analysis

During my GIS Certificate coursework, I developed compelling visualizations of Trevor Project data to tell the story of how anti-LGBTQ+ state legislation relates to the LGBTQ+ youth mental health crisis. I created this map using ArcGIS Pro and Adobe Illustrator. 

<br>

Key skills: ArcGIS Pro, Adobe Illustrator, Cartography, data storytelling

<br>

<br>

Key skills: PostgreSQL, ArcGISPro, database design, spatial analysis, team collaboration
